text:
A Procter & Gamble Investor Update: Growth and Transformational Objectives 
P&G at XLP Conference On September 10, 2015, The Procter & Gamble Company (PG), or P&G, presented at the Barclays Global Consumer Staples (XLP) Conference. Chief Financial Officer Jon Moeller highlighted the company’s recent results and talked about the transformational moves P&G is making in order to revive its top line and improve profitability.

About P&G P&G is the largest household and personal products company in the world. P&G and its subsidiaries manufacture and sell consumer-packaged goods. Some of the company’s most famous brands include Pampers, Tide, Head & Shoulders, and Gillette. To learn more about P&G’s business, please read the series Procter & Gamble: Your Guide to the Largest Consumer Staples Firm .
Results update In 4Q15 P&G’s adjusted EPS (earnings per share) grew by 8% in reported terms and by 22% on constant currency terms, to $1. This was primarily due to a $0.09 per share benefit from non-operating income, primarily from minor brand divestitures gains. For fiscal 2015, P&G’s organic sales grew in all segments except the beauty, hair, and personal care. Overall organic sales grew by 1% for fiscal 2015.
Stronger dollar impact The company’s results were adversely impacted by foreign exchange currencies. P&G’s large positions in Russia, Ukraine, and Japan compared to other companies like Colgate-Palmolive Company (CL), Kimberly-Clark (KMB), and Estée Lauder (EL) and have led to an even higher impact from the appreciating dollar, as these markets are heavily affected by forex headwinds.
To learn more about P&G’s 4Q15 and fiscal 2015 results, please read Earnings Analysis: Procter & Gamble’s Performance in Fiscal 2015 .
Forward-looking The company plans to focus on four transformations to category business models based on superior product offerings:
productivity supply chain portfolio rededication We’ll discuss these transformational moves in more detail throughout this 10-part series.
After P&G’s beauty brands merger with Coty (COTY), P&G plans to focus on core categories like its baby care, fabric care, hair care, and grooming segments, as they represent 60% of the company’s enterprise value and profits. P&G is taking priority away from its less profitable, non-strategic brands and product lines to improve the profitability of the business.
P&G has exposure in the iShares Core S&P 500 ETF (IVV), with 1.1% of the total weight of the portfolio as of September 11, 2015.
In the next part of this series, we’ll look at P&G’s divestiture of its beauty brands to Coty.
